docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Thumb sucking can lead to buck teeth. THE FACTS -- Most parents cringe at the sight of their children sucking their thumbs. Bacteria and germs, of course, are one issue. But another concern is the timeworn belief that thumb sucking can lead to the development of buck teeth, a notion that despite its reputation as an old wives' tale is no exaggeration. About 80 percent of infants and children suck their thumbs. The behavior is considered normal during the first four years of life, driven by a natural desire that was at some point probably essential to survival. But it starts to cause problems when continued past a certain age.
docs.snippet: Despite its reputation as an old wives' tale, the notion that thumb sucking can lead to the development of buck teeth is no exaggeration.

docs.lead_paragraph: Smokers who hope to avoid serious illness by limiting their intake to a few cigarettes a day may be making a big mistake. Writing in the current issue of Tobacco Control, researchers report that even people who smoke as few as one to four cigarettes a day significantly increase their risk of death from lung cancer or heart disease.

headline.main: A Few Cigarettes a Day Can Kill, Too

docs.snippet: Smokers who hope to avoid serious illness by limiting their intake to a few cigarettes a day may be making a big mistake.     Writing in the current issue of Tobacco Control, researchers report that even people who smoke as few as one to four...

docs.lead_paragraph: If you are heading out for a concert, you should consider taking a pair of earplugs. That is the advice of a new study that found that people who attend indoor concerts where the music is amplified show measurable hearing loss afterward.

headline.main: What Amplified Music Is the Loudest? All of It

docs.snippet: If you are heading out for a concert, you should consider taking a pair of earplugs.

docs.lead_paragraph: Once the water recedes, mud is hauled away and families are reunited with those who survived Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, most of the displaced residents will be focused on finding new places to live and work. But it will be equally important to pay attention to the effects of these vast disruptions on the mental health of children whose lives were torn apart. In an almost prophetic coincidence, in the September issue of the journal Pediatrics, experts from the American Academy of Pediatrics published a 10-page report to help pediatricians deal with the psychosocial effects of traumatic events -- natural disasters and acts of terrorism -- on children of all ages.

headline.main: After the Hurricanes, the Inner Storm for Children

docs.snippet: Once the water recedes, it will be vitally important to pay attention to the effects of the hurricanes on the mental health of children.

docs.lead_paragraph: How dedicated are Red Sox fans? Let's just say that according to a new study, when a big game is on television, Boston emergency rooms see a lot less business coming through the door. Emergency room doctors have long noted that when a major sporting event is going on, fewer people come in for treatment.

headline.main: Red Sox Fever and the Lonely Emergency Room

docs.snippet: How dedicated are Red Sox fans? Let's just say that according to a new study, when a big game is on television Boston emergency rooms see a lot less business coming through the door.

docs.lead_paragraph: With a new, highly contagious canine flu spreading, dogs that are coughing should be kept at home for up to two weeks, a scientist who first described the illness said yesterday. The scientist, Dr. Cynda Crawford, an immunologist at the University of Florida College of Veterinary Medicine and an author of a report on the canine influenza being released today by the journal Science, spoke at a news conference sponsored by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline.main: Scientist Recommends Isolation for Animals Showing Signs of Canine Flu

docs.snippet: With a new, highly contagious canine flu spreading, dogs that are coughing should be kept at home for up to two weeks, a scientist who first described the illness said yesterday.     The scientist, Dr. Cynda Crawford, an immunologist at the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Most people say they wash their hands after using the bathroom. But a new study suggests that many of them are not telling the truth. The researchers demonstrated that people were not as conscientious as they say they were by comparing answers given in a telephone poll to observed behavior.

headline.main: Many Don't Wash Hands After Using the Bathroom

docs.snippet: Most people say they wash their hands after using the bathroom. But a new study suggests that many of them are not telling the truth.

docs.lead_paragraph: Though we saw him as fearless, my father died without being told he had cancer. It was a choice my sister and I made despite the fervent protests of medical professionals, including my husband, a doctor. Our decision was based on knowing a man who, despite having survived the Holocaust and a New York stabbing, was terrified of only one thing -- cancer.

headline.main: We Never Told Our Father He Had Cancer

docs.snippet: Our decision was based on knowing a man who, despite having survived the Holocaust and a New York stabbing, was terrified of only one thing  cancer.

docs.lead_paragraph: Bosses dismiss employees. Spouses divorce each other. Patients leave their doctors. But can doctors ever fire their patients? This is not a topic most doctors like to talk about openly. Sure, many physicians I know, myself included, have occasionally wanted to fire a difficult or abusive patient, but no one really knows how often it happens.

headline.main: Should a Doctor Fire a Patient? Sometimes It Is Good Medicine

docs.snippet: Can doctors ever fire their patients? When it is best for the patient, the answer can be yes.

docs.lead_paragraph: In briefing consumers on health risks, public health campaigns often rely on a catchy strategy: they list the myths about a behavior or product, then follow up those misconceptions with the truth. Check any Internet search engine and you will find ''myths and facts'' on health topics like abortion, acne, vaccines and weight loss. But new research suggests that even the sharpest consumer can be tripped up by these warnings because of a flaw in the way we remember what we read or are told.

headline.main: In Heeding Health Warnings, Memory Can Be Tricky

docs.snippet: The catchy strategy of public health campaigns listing the myths and facts of health risks may actually backfire.
